name: Bag End to Rivendell
description: Frodo and company leave for Rivendell.

legs.day_full: Frodo and Company leave for Rivendell
legs.directions: Leave Bag End at full dark (7 p.m.). Go around west end, jump hedge.
legs.quote: ‘Well, now we’re off at last!’ said Frodo. They shouldered their packs and took up their sticks, and walked round the corner to the west side of Bag End. ‘Good-bye!’ said Frodo, looking at the dark blank windows. He waved his hand, and then turned and (following Bilbo, if he had known it) hurried after Peregrin down the garden-path. They jumped over the low place in the hedge at the bottom and took to the fields, passing into the darkness like a rustle in the grasses.

legs.day_full: Frodo and Company leave for Rivendell
legs.directions: Go through gate into a lane. Head west.
legs.quote: At the bottom of the Hill on its western side they came to the gate opening on to a narrow lane. There they halted and adjusted the straps of their packs. Presently Sam appeared, trotting quickly and breathing hard; his heavy pack was hoisted high on his shoulders, and he had put on his head a tall shapeless felt bag, which he called a hat. In the gloom he looked very much like a dwarf.

legs.day_full: Frodo and Company leave for Rivendell
legs.directions: Leave lane, follow hedgerows south.
legs.quote: For a short way they followed the lane westwards. Then leaving it they turned left and took quietly to the fields again. They went in single file along hedgerows and the borders of coppices, and night fell dark about them. In their dark cloaks they were as invisible as if they all had magic rings.

legs.day_full: Frodo and Company leave for Rivendell
legs.directions: Cross the Water on a plank bridge
legs.quote: After some time they crossed the Water, west of Hobbiton, by a narrow plank-bridge. The stream was there no more than a winding black ribbon, bordered with leaning alder-trees.

legs.day_full: Frodo and Company leave for Rivendell
legs.directions: Cross the great road from the Brandywine Bridge. Enter Tookland.
legs.quote: A mile or two further south they hastily crossed the great road from the Brandywine Bridge; they were now in the Tookland and bending south-eastwards they made for the Green Hill Country.

legs.day_full: Frodo and Company leave for Rivendell
legs.directions: Look back at lights of Hobbiton from first slopes of the Green Hill Country.
legs.quote: As they began to climb its [Green Hill Country's] first slopes they looked back and saw the lamps in Hobbiton far off twinkling in the gentle valley of the Water.

legs.day_full: Frodo and Company leave for Rivendell
legs.directions: Follow rising and falling slopes.
legs.quote: Soon [Hobbiton] disappeared in the folds of the darkened land, and was followed by Bywater beside its grey pool. When the light of the last farm was far behind, peeping among the trees, Frodo turned and waved a hand in farewell. ‘I wonder if I shall ever look down into that valley again,’ he said quietly.

legs.day_full: Frodo and Company leave for Rivendell
legs.directions: Stop in a birch grove for dinner.
legs.quote: When they had walked for about three hours they rested. The night was clear, cool, and starry, but smoke-like wisps of mist were creeping up the hill-sides from the streams and deep meadows. Thin-clad birches, swaying in a light wind above their heads, made a black net against the pale sky. They ate a very frugal supper (for hobbits), and then went on again.

legs.day_full: Frodo and Company leave for Rivendell
legs.directions: Follow road to Stock
legs.quote: Soon they struck a narrow road, that went rolling up and down, fading grey into the darkness ahead: the road to Woodhall, and Stock, and the Bucklebury Ferry. It climbed away from the main road in the Water-valley, and wound over the skirts of the Green Hills towards Woody End, a wild corner of the Eastfarthing.

legs.day_full: Frodo and Company leave for Rivendell
legs.directions: Begin to sing. Follow track between tall trees.
legs.quote: After a while they plunged into a deeply cloven track between tall trees that rustled their dry leaves in the night. It was very dark. At first they talked, or hummed a tune softly together, being now far away from inquisitive ears.

legs.day_full: Frodo and Company leave for Rivendell
legs.directions: Climb a steep slope until close to midnight.
legs.quote: Then they marched on in silence, and Pippin began to lag behind. At last, as they began to climb a steep slope, he stopped and yawned. ‘I am so sleepy,’ he said, ‘that soon I shall fall down on the road. Are you going to sleep on your legs? It is nearly midnight.’

legs.day_full: Frodo and Company leave for Rivendell
legs.directions: Camp in a firwood near the top of the hill. Sleep by a large tree. Surprise visitor.
legs.quote: Just over the top of the hill they came on the patch of fir-wood. Leaving the road they went into the deep resin-scented darkness of the trees, and gathered dead sticks and cones to make a fire. Soon they had a merry crackle of flame at the foot of a large fir-tree and they sat round it for a while, until they began to nod. Then, each in an angle of the great tree’s roots, they curled up in their cloaks and blankets, and were soon fast asleep. They set no watch; even Frodo feared no danger yet, for they were still in the heart of the Shire. A few creatures came and looked at them when the fire had died away. A fox passing through the wood on business of his own stopped several minutes and sniffed. ‘Hobbits!’ he thought. ‘Well, what next? I have heard of strange doings in this land, but I have seldom heard of a hobbit sleeping out of doors under a tree. Three of them! There’s something mighty queer behind this.’ He was quite right, but he never found out any more about it.

legs.directions: Eat and drink at little waterfall. Leave after 10:00 a.m.
legs.quote: There was a stream at the foot of the hill. They filled their bottles and the small camping kettle at a little fall where the water fell a few feet over an outcrop of grey stone. It was icy cold; and they spluttered and puffed as they bathed their faces and hands.

legs.directions: Follow rolling roads.
legs.quote: They went down the slope, and across the stream where it dived under the road, and up the next slope, and up and down another shoulder of the hills; and by that time their cloaks, blankets, water, food, and other gear already seemed a heavy burden.

legs.directions: Follow zig-zag road until you can see the river. Camp and rest from 1:30–4:30 p.m.
legs.quote: The day’s march promised to be warm and tiring work. After some miles, however, the road ceased to roll up and down: it climbed to the top of a steep bank in a weary zig-zagging sort of way, and then prepared to go down for the last time. In front of them they saw the lower lands dotted with small clumps of trees that melted away in the distance to a brown woodland haze. They were looking across the Woody End towards the Brandywine River. The road wound away before them like a piece of string.

legs.directions: Follow straight road. Get the first taste of the adventure ahead of you.
legs.quote: They were now on level ground, and the road after much winding lay straight ahead through grass-land sprinkled with tall trees, outliers of the approaching woods. […] The sound of hoofs drew nearer. Just in time he threw himself down in a patch of long grass behind a tree that overshadowed the road. Then he lifted his head and peered cautiously above one of the great roots. Round the corner came a black horse, no hobbit-pony but a full-sized horse; and on it sat a large man, who seemed to crouch in the saddle, wrapped in a great black cloak and hood, so that only his boots in the high stirrups showed below; his face was shadowed and invisible.

legs.directions: Keep left of the road.
legs.quote: The shadows of the trees were long and thin on the grass, as they started off again. They now kept a stone’s throw to the left of the road, and kept out of sight of it as much as they could. But this hindered them; for the grass was thick and tussocky, and the ground uneven, and the trees began to draw together into thickets.

legs.directions: At crossroads, do not follow the Stock Road left, but go right towards the wood of ancient oaks. Camp (6:30 p.m.) and rest.
legs.quote: Not far from the road-meeting they came on the huge hulk of a tree: it was still alive and had leaves on the small branches that it had put out round the broken stumps of its long-fallen limbs; but it was hollow, and could be entered by a great crack on the side away from the road. The hobbits crept inside, and sat there upon a floor of old leaves and decayed wood. They rested and had a light meal, talking quietly and listening from time to time.

legs.directions: Go on in twilight. Begin to sing. (ca. 7:00 p.m.)
legs.quote:
Upon the hearth the fire is red,
Beneath the roof there is a bed;
But not yet weary are our feet,
Still round the corner we may meet
A sudden tree or standing stone
That none have seen but we alone.
Tree and flower and leaf and grass,
Let them pass! Let them pass!
Hill and water under sky,
Pass them by! Pass them by!

legs.directions: Nightfall. Followed by enemies, find unexpected help.
legs.quote:
O Elbereth! Gilthoniel!
We still remember, we who dwell
In this far land beneath the trees,
Thy starlight on the Western Seas.

legs.directions: Follow the Elves on a low lane through dense hazel woods.
legs.quote: They now marched on again in silence, and passed like shadows and faint lights: for Elves (even more than hobbits) could walk when they wished without sound or footfall. Pippin soon began to feel sleepy, and staggered once or twice; but each time a tall Elf at his side put out his arm and saved him from a fall. Sam walked along at Frodo’s side, as if in a dream, with an expression on his face half of fear and half of astonished joy.

legs.directions: Turn right off the path on a green ride through thickets.
legs.quote: At last the Elves turned aside from the path. A green ride lay almost unseen through the thickets on the right; and this they followed as it wound away back up the wooded slopes on to the top of a shoulder of the hills that stood out into the lower land of the river-valley.

legs.directions: Camp near Woodhall. Get sage advice.
legs.quote: ‘Can’t a hobbit walk from the Water to the River in peace?’ ‘But it is not your own Shire,’ said Gildor. ‘Others dwelt here before hobbits were; and others will dwell here again when hobbits are no more. The wide world is all about you: you can fence yourselves in, but you cannot for ever fence it out.’

legs.directions: Sleep late. Discuss route, decide to cut directly towards Buckleberry Ferry.
legs.quote: ‘Short cuts make long delays,’ argued Pippin. ‘The country is rough round here, and there are bogs and all kinds of difficulties down in the Marish – I know the land in these parts. And if you are worrying about Black Riders, I can’t see that it is any worse meeting them on a road than in a wood or a field.’

legs.directions: Meet a deep-banked stream, continue alongside it.
legs.quote: On the edge high above them they saw against the sky a horse standing. Beside it stooped a black figure. They at once gave up any idea of going back. Frodo led the way, and plunged quickly into the thick bushes beside the stream.

legs.directions: Cross to the south bank of the stream.
legs.quote: ‘Why, this is the Stock-brook!’ said Pippin. ‘If we are going to try and get back on to our course, we must cross at once and bear right.’

legs.directions: Continue to a belt of trees among beginning rain.
legs.quote: They came again to a belt of trees: tall oaks, for the most part, with here and there an elm tree or an ash. The ground was fairly level, and there was little undergrowth; but the trees were too close for them to see far ahead. The leaves blew upwards in sudden gusts of wind, and spots of rain began to fall from the overcast sky. Then the wind died away and the rain came streaming down.

legs.directions: Realise you've turned too far south.
legs.quote: After half an hour Pippin said: ‘I hope we have not turned too much towards the south, and are not walking longwise through this wood! It is not a very broad belt – I should have said no more than a mile at the widest – and we ought to have been through it by now.’ ‘It is no good our starting to go in zig-zags,’ said Frodo. ‘That won’t mend matters. Let us keep on as we are going! I am not sure that I want to come out into the open yet.’

legs.directions: Stop for lunch at 2 p.m. Eat and sing for an hour until rudely interrupted by an ominous cry.
legs.quote:
Ho! Ho! Ho! to the bottle I go
To heal my heart and drown my woe.
Rain may fall and wind may blow,
And many miles be still to go,
But under a tall tree I will lie,
And let the clouds go sailing by.

legs.directions: Wood ends.
legs.quote: Before long the wood came to a sudden end. Wide grass-lands stretched before them. They now saw that they had, in fact, turned too much to the south. Away over the flats they could glimpse the low hill of Bucklebury across the River, but it was now to their left.

legs.directions: Reach area of the Marish.
legs.quote: At first they felt afraid, away from the shelter of the wood. Far back behind them stood the high place where they had breakfasted. Frodo half expected to see the small distant figure of a horseman on the ridge dark against the sky; but there was no sign of one. The sun escaping from the breaking clouds, as it sank towards the hills they had left, was now shining brightly again. Their fear left them, though they still felt uneasy. But the land became steadily more tame and well-ordered. Soon they came into well-tended fields and meadows: there were hedges and gates and dikes for drainage. Everything seemed quiet and peaceful, just an ordinary corner of the Shire. Their spirits rose with every step.

legs.directions: Follow way along a turnip field to the gate
legs.quote: They passed along the edge of a huge turnip-field, and came to a stout gate. Beyond it a rutted lane ran between low well-laid hedges towards a distant clump of trees. Pippin stopped. ‘I know these fields and this gate!’ he said. ‘This is Bamfurlong, old Farmer Maggot’s land. That’s his farm away there in the trees.’

legs.directions: Follow the way alongside Farmer Maggot's fields.
legs.quote: ‘I am terrified of him and his dogs. I have avoided his farm for years and years. He caught me several times trespassing after mushrooms, when I was a youngster at Brandy Hall. On the last occasion he beat me, and then took me and showed me to his dogs. “See, lads,” he said, “next time this young varmint sets foot on my land, you can eat him. Now see him off!” They chased me all the way to the Ferry. I have never got over the fright – though I daresay the beasts knew their business and would not really have touched me.’

legs.directions: Continue to Farmer Maggot's house
legs.quote: They went into the farmer’s kitchen, and sat by the wide fire-place. Mrs. Maggot brought out beer in a huge jug, and filled four large mugs. It was a good brew, and Pippin found himself more than compensated for missing the Golden Perch.

legs.directions: Ride in wagon. Follow lane to the causeway to Buckleberry Ferry.
legs.quote: There was now no breath of wind stirring; the night was still and quiet, and a chill was in the air. They went without lights and took it slowly. After a mile or two the lane came to an end, crossing a deep dike, and climbing a short slope up on to the high-banked causeway. Maggot got down and took a good look either way, north and south, but nothing could be seen in the darkness, and there was not a sound in the still air. Thin strands of river-mist were hanging above the dikes, and crawling over the fields.

legs.directions: Get to the ferry through the thick fog, meet Merry.
legs.quote: Merry led the pony over a gangway on to the ferry, and the others followed. Merry then pushed slowly off with a long pole. The Brandy-wine flowed slow and broad before them. On the other side the bank was steep, and up it a winding path climbed from the further landing. Lamps were twinkling there. Behind loomed up the Buck Hill; and out of it, through stray shrouds of mist, shone many round windows, yellow and red. They were the windows of Brandy Hall, the ancient home of the Brandybucks.

legs.directions: Take the main road south from the ferry, then a right into the country.
legs.quote: It was some distance from the Brandywine to Frodo’s new house at Crickhollow. They passed Buck Hill and Brandy Hall on their left, and on the outskirts of Bucklebury struck the main road of Buckland that ran south from the Bridge. Half a mile northward along this they came to a lane opening on their right. This they followed for a couple of miles as it climbed up and down into the country.

legs.directions: Reach Crickhollow. Spend the night and confess to your friends what you're up to.
legs.quote:
O! Water is fair that leaps on high
in a fountain white beneath the sky;
but never did fountain sound so sweet
as splashing Hot Water with my feet!.

legs.directions: Leave on ponies, soon after 6:00 a.m.
legs.quote:
To Rivendell, where Elves yet dwell
In glades beneath the misty fell,
Through moor and waste we ride in haste,
And whither then we cannot tell.

legs.directions: Take tunnel under the Hedge to reach the Old Forest. Follow path until it disappears
legs.quote: The trees do not like strangers. They watch you. They are usually content merely to watch you, as long as daylight lasts, and don’t do much. Occasionally the most unfriendly ones may drop a branch, or stick a root out, or grasp at you with a long trailer. […] They do say the trees do actually move, and can surround strangers and hem them in. In fact long ago they attacked the Hedge: they came and planted themselves right by it, and leaned over it. But the hobbits came and cut down hundreds of trees, and made a great bonfire in the Forest, and burned all the ground in a long strip east of the Hedge. After that the trees gave up the attack, but they became very unfriendly. There is still a wide bare space not far inside where the bonfire was made.

legs.directions: Reach Bonfire Glade. Follow the path beyond.
legs.quote: ‘Well, well!’ he said. ‘These trees do shift. There is the Bonfire Glade in front of us (or I hope so), but the path to it seems to have moved away!’

legs.directions: Follow the gently climbing path.
legs.quote:
O! Wanderers in the shadowed land
despair not! For though dark they stand,
all woods there be must end at last,
and see the open sun go past:
the setting sun, the rising sun,
the day’s end, or the day begun.
For east or west all woods must fail …

legs.directions: Rest and eat on top of knoll, surrounded by oppressive trees.
legs.quote: They sat on the green edge and looked out over the woods below them, while they ate their mid-day meal. As the sun rose and passed noon they glimpsed far off in the east the grey-green lines of the Downs that lay beyond the Old Forest on that side. That cheered them greatly; for it was good to see a sight of anything beyond the wood’s borders, though they did not mean to go that way, if they could help it: the Barrow-downs had as sinister a reputation in hobbit-legend as the Forest itself.

legs.directions: Leave the path when it veers south-east, and try to turn north.
legs.quote: At first their choice seemed to be good: they got along at a fair speed, though whenever they got a glimpse of the sun in an open glade they seemed unaccountably to have veered eastwards. But after a time the trees began to close in again, just where they had appeared from a distance to be thinner and less tangled.

legs.directions: Lose directions while crossing several deep folds and trying to keep eastward direction.
legs.quote: Each time they clambered out, the trees seemed deeper and darker; and always to the left and upwards it was most difficult to find a way, and they were forced to the right and downwards.

legs.directions: Give up when you enter a fold too deep to leave, and follow it south-east to Withywindle, the worst part of the forest.
legs.quote: As if through a gate they saw the sunlight before them. Coming to the opening they found that they had made their way down through a cleft in a high steep bank, almost a cliff. At its feet was a wide space of grass and reeds; and in the distance could be glimpsed another bank almost as steep. A golden afternoon of late sunshine lay warm and drowsy upon the hidden land between. In the midst of it there wound lazily a dark river of brown water, bordered with ancient willows, arched over with willows, blocked with fallen willows, and flecked with thousands of faded willow-leaves. The air was thick with them, fluttering yellow from the branches; for there was a warm and gentle breeze blowing softly in the valley, and the reeds were rustling, and the willow-boughs were creaking.

legs.directions: Find path along the river, follow it east through wetlands.
legs.quote: Everywhere the reeds and grasses were lush and tall, in places far above their heads; but once found, the path was easy to follow, as it turned and twisted, picking out the sounder ground among the bogs and pools. Here and there it passed over other rills, running down gullies into the Withywindle out of the higher forest-lands, and at these points there were tree-trunks or bundles of brushwood laid carefully across.

legs.directions: Stop by Old Man Willow to rest. It's fine. Promise.
legs.quote: Pippin had vanished. The crack by which he had laid himself had closed together, so that not a chink could be seen. Merry was trapped: another crack had closed about his waist; his legs lay outside, but the rest of him was inside a dark opening, the edges of which gripped like a pair of pincers.

legs.directions: Reach Tom Bombadil's house among the stars rising.
legs.quote:
Hey! Come derry dol! Hop along, my hearties!
Hobbits! Ponies all! We are fond of parties.
Now let the fun begin! Let us sing together!

legs.directions: Rain. Spend the day at Tom Bombadils house.
legs.quote:
Ho! Tom Bombadil, Tom Bombadillo!
By water, wood and hill, by the reed and willow,
By fire, sun and moon, harken now and hear us!
Come, Tom Bombadil, for our need is near us!

legs.directions: Leave Tom's house and enter the Barrow-downs where the evil Barrow-wights from Angmar dwell.
legs.quote: He turned his glance eastwards, and he saw that on that side the hills were higher and looked down upon them; and all those hills were crowned with green mounds, and on some were standing stones, pointing upwards like jagged teeth out of green gums. That view was somehow disquieting; so they turned from the sight.

legs.directions: Midday. Stop in a hollow atop a hill. Eat and fall asleep. Wake in fog, sun sinking.
legs.quote: They found that they were upon an island in the fog. Even as they looked out in dismay towards the setting sun, it sank before their eyes into a white sea, and a cold grey shadow sprang up in the East behind. The fog rolled up to the walls and rose above them, and as it mounted it bent over their heads until it became a roof: they were shut in a hall of mist whose central pillar was the standing stone.

legs.directions: Try to head north, but get lost and separated, easily prey for Barrow-wights.
legs.quote:
Cold be hand and heart and bone,
and cold be sleep under stone:
never more to wake on stony bed,
never, till the Sun fails and the Moon is dead.
In the black wind the stars shall die,
and still on gold here let them lie,
till the dark lord lifts his hand
over dead sea and withered land.

legs.directions: Get rescued by Tom Bombadil.
legs.quote:
Get out, you old Wight! Vanish in the sunlight!
Shrivel like the cold mist, like the winds go wailing,
Out into the barren lands far beyond the mountains!
Come never here again! Leave your barrow empty!
Lost and forgotten be, darker than the darkness,
Where gates stand for ever shut, till the world is mended.

legs.directions: Follow Tom Bombadil north after looting the barrow.
legs.quote: For each of the hobbits he chose a dagger, long, leaf-shaped, and keen, of marvellous workmanship, damasked with serpent-forms in red and gold. They gleamed as he drew them from their black sheaths, wrought of some strange metal, light and strong, and set with many fiery stones. Whether by some virtue in these sheaths or because of the spell that lay on the mound, the blades seemed untouched by time, unrusted, sharp, glittering in the sun.

legs.directions: Cross dike and hedge, the former boundary of Cardolan, part of the North Kingdom of Arnor.
legs.quote: The dark line they had seen was not a line of trees but a line of bushes growing on the edge of a deep dike with a steep wall on the further side. Tom said that it had once been the boundary of a kingdom, but a very long time ago. He seemed to remember something sad about it, and would not say much.

legs.directions: Return to Great East Road, where Tom departs.
legs.quote:
Tom’s country ends here: he will not pass the borders.
Tom has his house to mind, and Goldberry is waiting!
legs.comment: Strider sees the hobbits here, but stays hidden.

legs.directions: Reach the Prancing Pony in Bree.
legs.quote:
There is an inn, a merry old inn
beneath an old grey hill,
And there they brew a beer so brown
That the Man in the Moon himself came down
one night to drink his fill.

legs.directions: Survive the Night. Leave Bree on East Road.
legs.quote:
All that is gold does not glitter,
Not all those who wander are lost;
The old that is strong does not wither,
Deep roots are not reached by the frost.
From the ashes a fire shall be woken,
A light from the shadows shall spring;
Renewed shall be blade that was broken,
The crownless again shall be king.

legs.directions: Leave road and head north into Chetwood.
legs.quote: At last they left the village behind. The escort of children and stragglers that had followed them got tired and turned back at the South-gate. Passing through, they kept on along the Road for some miles. It bent to the left, curving back into its eastward line as it rounded the feet of Bree-hill, and then it began to run swiftly downwards into wooded country. To their left they could see some of the houses and hobbit-holes of Staddle on the gentler south-eastern slopes of the hill; down in a deep hollow away north of the Road there were wisps of rising smoke that showed where Combe lay; Archet was hidden in the trees beyond.

legs.directions: Camp in Chetwood, east of Archet.
legs.quote: His plan, as far as they could understand it without knowing the country, was to go towards Archet at first, but to bear right and pass it on the east, and then to steer as straight as he could over the wild lands to Weathertop Hill. In that way they would, if all went well, cut off a great loop of the Road, which further on bent southwards to avoid the Midgewater Marshes. But, of course, they would have to pass through the marshes themselves, and Strider’s description of them was not encouraging.

legs.directions: Head east. Ground dropping slowly. Quiet and peaceful.
legs.quote: Whether because of Strider’s skill or for some other reason, they saw no sign and heard no sound of any other living thing all that day: neither two-footed, except birds; nor four-footed, except one fox and a few squirrels.

legs.directions: Camp in eastern Chetwood.
legs.quote: The next day they began to steer a steady course eastwards; and still all was quiet and peaceful.

legs.directions: Leave the Chetwood.
legs.quote: On the third day out from Bree they came out of the Chetwood. The land had been falling steadily, ever since they turned aside from the Road, and they now entered a wide flat expanse of country, much more difficult to manage.

legs.directions: Enter the western edge of Midgewater Marshes.
legs.quote: The ground now became damp, and in places boggy and here and there they came upon pools, and wide stretches of reeds and rushes filled with the warbling of little hidden birds. They had to pick their way carefully to keep both dry-footed and on their proper course. […] The marshes were bewildering and treacherous, and there was no permanent trail even for Rangers to find through their shifting quagmires. The flies began to torment them, and the air was full of clouds of tiny midges that crept up their sleeves and breeches and into their hair.

legs.directions: Camp in western part of the Marshes.
legs.quote: They spent a miserable day in this lonely and unpleasant country. Their camping-place was damp, cold, and uncomfortable; and the biting insects would not let them sleep. There were also abominable creatures haunting the reeds and tussocks that from the sound of them were evil relatives of the cricket. There were thousands of them, and they squeaked all round, neek-breek, breek-neek, unceasingly all the night, until the hobbits were nearly frantic.

legs.directions: Camp in eastern part of the Marshes.
legs.quote: The next day, the fourth, was little better, and the night almost as comfortless. Though the Neekerbreekers (as Sam called them) had been left behind, the midges still pursued them.
legs.comment: This is when Gandalf is on Weathertop. They see his flashes of light at night.

legs.directions: Reach eastern edge of the Marshes, towards Weather Hills ahead, into dry and barren country.
legs.quote: ‘I think,’ answered Strider slowly, as if he was not quite sure, ‘I think the best thing is to go as straight eastward from here as we can, to make for the line of hills, not for Weathertop. There we can strike a path I know that runs at their feet; it will bring us to Weathertop from the north and less openly. Then we shall see what we shall see.’

legs.directions: Camp by a stream, among stunted alder trees.
legs.quote: All that day they plodded along, until the cold and early evening came down. The land became drier and more barren; but mists and vapours lay behind them on the marshes. A few melancholy birds were piping and wailing, until the round red sun sank slowly into the western shadows; then an empty silence fell.

legs.directions: Set out after sunrise towards the crumbled ruins on Hills ahead.
legs.quote: The hobbits felt refreshed, as if they had had a night of unbroken sleep. Already they were getting used to much walking on short commons – shorter at any rate than what in the Shire they would have thought barely enough to keep them on their legs. Pippin declared that Frodo was looking twice the hobbit that he had been. ‘Very odd,’ said Frodo, tightening his belt, ‘considering that there is actually a good deal less of me. I hope the thinning process will not go on indefinitely, or I shall become a wraith.’

legs.comment: Reach foot of the Weather Hills. Camp there.
Follow path south toward Weathertop: path is cunningly hidden and is edged with stones where land is open. Sam recites part of The Fall of Gil-galad.
Midday - Near south end of path. Reach dell at western foot of hill.
Climb to top of Weathertop and enter the ruins of the watch Tower of Amon Sûl. See Black Riders on road below.
Return to dell. Camp there. Attack of Nazgul at night.
Injured, Frodo is carried on pony. Head south from dell.
Cross Great East Road and enter thickets on south side. Land slopes south.
Camp in thickets.
Camp.
Camp - Follow a wide shallow curving valley.
Camp - Continue in valley.
Continue in valley. Land starts to rise. Can see huddle of hills ahead.
Camp not far SW of bridge. Camp is high enough for Merry to see the Loudwater far in the distance!
Return to The Great East Road
Strider scouts ahead and finds an elf-stone on The Last Bridge. He believes it is a token of safety. Company crosses the River Hoarwell/Mitheithel.
Turn north from the Road. Enter the steep lands of the Trollshaws. They can see ruined walls and towers frowning down.
Hills quickly shut them in. Difficult going. Camp.
More climbing.
Weather turns wet during the day.
Hills higher and steeper. They are forced north out of their way. Still raining. Camp on a stony shelf by a shallow cave.

Rain stops. Strider scouts. Start late. Turn SE, scrambling over rocky ground. Find a valley, but it ends in a high ridge. Climb ridge and camp in a saddle at top. COLD. Build a fire under a gnarled pine.
Slope beyond ridge is much easier. Bright, fair day. Strider briefly sees the Loudwater/Bruinen in the distance.
Reach a trail.
Find Troll-hole. Continue on level path through woods.
Stone Trolls. Rest. Sam recites Old Troll. Continue in afternoon. Woods.
Return to the Road.
While looking for a place to camp, hear a horse: Glorfindel.
March all night. Frodo is on Glorfindels horse. Camp next to the road at dawn.
Camp less than 5 hours. Take road with 2 brief rests.
Cross a small stream. Rest stop.
Rest stop.
Camp where road bends right to run down slope toward the River Bruinen.
Leave early morning, hobbling along (ca. 7 a.m.).
Road running downhill. Much grass on sides.
Road plunges through a cutting of red stone with tall pines. Glorfindel says Run!
Hobbits are halfway across grassy flat when Nazgul burst through behind them.
Attack at the Ford (ca. noon). Glorfindels horse carries Frodo across Ford. Nazgul drown. Frodo falls.
Company meets Elves sent from Rivendell (est. 2 p.m.). They take Frodo ahead. Rest of company follows on foot.
Come to the sudden cliff into the valley of Rivendell.
Frodo reaches Rivendell carried by the Elves (est. 4 p.m.). Others arrive in evening.

name: Rivendell to Lothlorien
description: The journey of the Fellowship of the Ring begins.

legs.comment: Leave Rivendell at dusk on Dec. 25.
Climb out of the valley onto the moors.
At the Ford of Brúinen, turn south on ‘narrow paths among folded lands’.
To the west the Bruinen cuts a steep-sided canyon.
Walk until dawn. Camp during the day - Dec. 26.
Empty country - rough and barren.
Cross a small stream.
Empty country - rough and barren.
Camp in a hollow during the day - Dec. 27.
Crest the top of a hill. Snowcapped peak lies due east.
Cold and windy. Camp during the day - Dec. 28.
Reach a small stream. Follow it west.
Leave streambed.
Paths few and winding. Camp during the day - Dec. 29.
After reaching the top of a rise, angle southeast.
Camp in a thicket of thorn bushes during the day - Dec. 30.
Reach crest of another low mountain spur. Turn southwest as they descend.
Path comes to a steep drop-off. Go along cliff-top for a while
Camp during the day - 1 Yule.
Cross a small stream.
Camp during the day - 2 Yule.
Another snowcapped peak lies to the east.
Camp during the day - Jan.1.
Cross a small stream. It flows west into a swampy area.
Camp during the day - Jan. 2. Continues cold, gray and windy.
After reaching a hilltop, turn southeast.
Camp during the day - Jan. 3.
Cross a small stream.
Camp during the day - Jan. 4.
Rolling lands.
Camp during the day - Jan. 5.
Camp during the day - Jan. 6.
Land drops more steeply. Go southeast into a valley.
Cross a small stream. Camp during the day - Jan. 7.
Weather warmer and sunny. Can see Mts. of Moria in distance. Eerily quiet.
Begin climb up north side of Hollin Ridge.
Reach Hollin Ridge. Large holly trees mark ridge. Day camp on Hollin Ridge. They plan to stay overnight, but after the crebain fly over, they leave at dusk.
Soon strike a good path that goes southeast toward the mountain pass. Path is lined with stones. Full moon.
Frodo and Gandalf sense something flying over just before dawn.
Cross a small stream. Camp during day of Jan. 9. Sunny, but colder.
Road begins climbing as it winds into the hills. Mountains are closer.
Camp during day of Jan. 10.
Road climbs still higher.
Almost to the feet of the Redhorn. Camp during day of Jan. 11. Gandalf and Aragorn debate path. Wind turns NW. Black clouds form during afternoon.
Leave camp at dusk. (ca. 5 p.m.). Fearing snow, each takes wood along.
Path is fairly smooth. They make good time.
Path becomes more steep and is dotted with fallen stones.
Path climbs a sharp slope: cliff on left, drop-off on right. Begins to snow as reach a ‘shelf’ at the top of the slope.
Snow begins to fall more thickly.
They stop briefly. Wind slackens. Snow lessens. Start again (ca. 8 p.m.).
Redhorn Pass. Snow becomes even heavier. Wind howls. Decide they can go no further. All huddle against the south-facing cliff, some behind Bill the Pony. Build fire. Stay until dawn.
Aragorn and Boromir start down, plowing through the snow.
Fellowship reaches great drift of snow. Clouds begin to break.
Snow steadily more shallow.
Back to shelf of stone ... no more snow (ca. 10:30 a.m.).
Turn west, away from path they took up to the Pass. Crebain return.
Turn more southwest around foothills of the Silvertine.
Stop to eat (ca.6 p.m.), camp, and debate. Cold wind. Hear Wargs! Climb to top of the hill above them. Enter a ring of stones with gnarled trees within. Wargs gather. Attack just before dawn.
Leave ca. 8 a.m. Head south-southeast toward the Sirannon.
A barren country of red stones.
Reach the Sirannon (ca. 11 a.m.). Dry. Head east on a path along stream.
Path lies in a deep trough. It is a rough, winding track.
Stop to EAT quickly (ca. 12:30 - 1 p.m.).
Fall of the Sirannon: Frodo, Gimli and Gandalf climb stairs to upland valley; return.
Climb curving road to upland valley. Most is filled with a lake.
Wade through stream at north end of lake.
Reach the Doors of Moria. (ca. 6 p.m.). Release Bill. Spend ca. ½ hour at Gate seeking the password. ATTACK by the Watcher in the Water.
Stop just inside Moria to eat and rest briefly. Leave ca. 7 p.m.
Frodo begins to hear Gollum’s pattering footsteps.
Stop to decide which path; brief halt.
Have to jump narrow fissure.
Have to jump 7 foot fissure; brief halt.
Reach junction of 3 passages, with Guardroom (ca. 1 a.m.). CAMP.
Leave Guardroom (ca. 8 a.m.). Take right hand passage.
Road climbs in great mounting curves with no side passages. (Est.) break.
(Est.) lunch and rest.
(Est.) break.
Reach the 21st Hall of the North End. Camp overnight.
(ca. 8 a.m.) Eat. Enter Chamber of Records nearby. Find Balin’s Tomb. ATTACK - orcs and cave troll. Escape through east door of room.
After descending 7 flights of stairs, REST.
Reach the 1st Deep. Fire blocks them from Orcs. Cross Bridge over Durin’s Deep. Balrog attacks. Gandalf and Balrog fall.
Rest escape up flight of steps, and out East Gate. Orcs flee. (ca.1 p.m.).
STOP to vent grief. Then continue down rough, winding trail.
Durin’s Stone and Mirrormere. Stop briefly, then continue south on road.
Pause at the spring of the Silverlode.
Frodo and Sam lag behind. Aragorn and Boromir carry them to a dell nearby. Eat and rest (ca. 3 to 4 p.m.).
Dusk (ca. 5 p.m.).
Frodo begins to hear Gollum again, and sees glowing eyes.
Enter woods of Lothlórien.
Cross the Nimrodel. Go west upstream a short distance. Meet elves. Sleep on       flets in the trees. Orc company passes during the night. Gollum appears briefly.
Start about 8 a.m. Clear and cold “like a cool summer day.” Follow path south beside the Silverlode.
Cross the Silverlode on ropes. Fellowship is blindfolded. Frodo notices paths are smooth, and he smells the trees and grass.
Pass through an open glade.
CAMP - Sleep on the ground. Still blindfolded.
Continue on path.
Noon - In a clearing, meet an elf-company. Blindfolds are removed.Climb to the top of the hill of Cerin Amroth. Can see all around. Stay there ca. 2 hours.
Elves light lanterns (ca. 5:30 p.m.).
Reach the north side of Caras Galadan. Early stars are out (ca. 6:10 p.m.).
Reach Gates of Caras Galadan (south side) and climb to meet Celeborn and Galadriel. Stay in Lothlórien until February 16.

Leave Caras Galadon after breakfast. Lembas, cloaks
and rope are provided. Haldir guides the Fellowship south and east through rolling woodlands, which fall away toward the rivers.
Noon – Reach grassy lawn on the Silverlode just west of the Anduin. Practice paddling. Meet swan-ship of Celeborn and Galadriel. Lunch and gift-giving. Leave in 3 small boats (ca. 1 p.m.).
DRIFT. Sweep around a bend, and high banks hide the light of Lórien.
Bare woods on both banks. Land is silent. Misty. Dusk comes early.
Camp in woods on west bank (ca. 8:30 p.m.). Dreary and cold.
Leave early (ca. 7:30 a.m.). Bare trees continue on both sides. DRIFT. No enemies.
Camp on west bank of the river.
Leave early. DRIFT. No enemies.
Trees thin. Gray and overcast.
Trees disappear. Begin to see withered downs on east at the north edge of the Brown Lands. Tall reedy plains on west. Can see west to hills and mountains.
Camp in flats north of the Field of Celebrant.
Leave early. Feel urgency. Paddle all day.
River broadens. Continues gray and overcast.
Reach North Undeep with stony beaches on east – gravel shoals in the water: go carefully.
River Limlight enters on west.
High wolds of the Brown Lands on east. Downs seen on the west.
Boromir mutters to himself. Just at dusk, Sam spots Gollum on a log.
Camp on small eyot near western shore. Sam and Frodo watch. Gollum appears during Frodo’s watch. Aragorn wakes. Watches until morning.

legs.day_full: 72 miles – Continue through much of the night (18 hours)
legs.comment: Leave early morning. Paddle long periods. Still overcast, east wind.

legs.day_full: 72 miles – Continue through much of the night (18 hours)
legs.comment: River curves east. Wolds on both sides.

legs.day_full: 72 miles – Continue through much of the night (18 hours)
legs.comment: River swings south. Still amid high hills.

legs.day_full: 72 miles – Continue through much of the night (18 hours)
legs.comment: North edge of eastern South Undeep.

legs.day_full: 72 miles – Continue through much of the night (18 hours)
legs.comment: Dusk. Continue through much of the night, paddling cautiously.

legs.day_full: 72 miles – Continue through much of the night (18 hours)
legs.comment: Downs on far (east) bank. Hills of the Wold on near bank.

legs.day_full: 72 miles – Continue through much of the night (18 hours)
legs.comment: Reach the north edge of western South Undeep.

legs.day_full: 72 miles – Continue through much of the night (18 hours)
legs.comment: Reach steep north face of south downs, inner ridge – hidden in the dark.

legs.day_full: 72 miles – Continue through much of the night (18 hours)
legs.comment: CAMP during DAY (Feb. 21). Downs on both sides of the river.
Leave at dusk. Paddle cautiously. Sky clears. Sam notices ‘rind’ of the new Moon.
North face of outer down ridge.
Reach lowlands between downs and the Emyn Muil.
CAMP during DAY (Feb. 22).
Leave at dusk. Paddle cautiously.
Banks grow stony. Hills north of the Emyn Muil rise on the east shore.
Hills also appear on the west. The river passes through “low crumbling cliffs, and chimneys with grey weathered stone dark with ivy.”
They reach the higher Emyn Muil.
Camp on west shore (Feb. 23). Many birds circle during the day.
Late in day Legolas sees eagle. Wait to full dark to leave (8:30 p.m.). Go slowly.

Midnight. Sam hears racing water. North edge of the rapids of Sarn Gebir. ORC ATTACK. Reach western shore. Legolas shoots a Nazgul’s flying beast. Move upstream to a small shallow bay. Huddle in boats rest of the night.
Foggy. Carry boats and packs to foot of rapids – 2 trips. Camp by pool that night.
Leave at full light (ca. 7:30 a.m.).
Brief, heavy rain.
They are in a wide ravine, with great rocky sides, and a few trees.
Channel grows narrower and the River swifter.
The Argonath. Boats are swept through the narrow gap between.
Chasm of the Gates bends slightly to the west.
Pass out of the chasm into the lake: Nen Hithoel. (ca. 2 p.m.).
Rest in boats and eat. Then paddle on.
Aragorn leads them toward the west bank.
Reach the lawn of Parth Galen below Amon Hen. “Rauros was calling with a great voice.” Camp there.

name: Rauros to Isengard (Hobbits)
description: After the Breaking of the Fellowship, Merry and Pippin get carried from Rauros to Isengard.

legs.comment: Breaking of the Fellowship. Pippin and Merry run from Parth Galen searching for Frodo (shortly before noon).
Boromir mortally wounded. Pippin and Merry captured by orcs (ca. 2 p.m.).
Orcs carry hobbits. Pass along many gullies and ravines which dissect the backslope of the eastern ridge of the Emyn Muil.
Descend the steep western cliff face.
Reach a stony trough between ridged hills. They turn north alongside the trickling stream runs through the trough.
Dusk. Pippin wakes, bound with ropes. Merry unconscious. Skirmish between Orcs of Mordor and Isengard. Pippin manages to cut the ropes on his wrists, then reties them.
Orcs climb the western ridge where stream comes out of a ravine.
Head of the stream. They continue up the ravine.
Reach crest of western ridge.
Go north along ridge.
Reach a narrow ravine with a noisy stream running through it. Climb down the cliff ‘20 fathoms’ (120 feet) to a ‘wide and rugged shelf.’

Early night. Reach the East Wall of Rohan – the sheer cliff which drops to the grassy plains on a path like a stony stair. Pippin awakes when he is thrown down. Scout reports seeing a Horseman. Uglúk smears ointment on Merry’s forehead and forces down an orc-draught to wake him. Both hobbits’ leg bindings are cut and they are forced to run.
They descend the sheer cliff of the shelf on a path like a stony stair.
In the grasslands orcs run with long, loping strides.
When they reach a muddy depression, Pippin swerves away from the main trail. As he is recaptured, he drops his elven brooch.
Merry and Pippin are carried again. They slip into dark dreams.
Far behind, the company is visible to Legolas.
Ground begins to rise toward the downs to the north.
Turn more to the north, parallel to the river Entwash. Dryer ground.
Reach the first slopes of the Downs. Many orcs demand a halt. Pippin and Merry are flung to the ground and sleep (ca.11 p.m).
Soon the hobbits are carried again, tossed and shaken.
North face of southern down ridge.
Rising crest of second down ridge.
Reach the most northerly hill of the Downs. Turn more toward the river.

Morning. Orcs stop near the Entwash. Mountains and forest can be seen ahead. Pippin is thrown on the grass. Merry is not far away. Eat. Riders of Rohan are seen to the south. Over 100 northern orcs flee north. Grisnákh returns from the east with 40 Orcs of Mordor. Isengarders carry the hobbits, changing off carriers.
Isengarders gradually pass through Orcs of Mordor. Hills of the Wold rise on the east.
Isengarders overtake Northerners. Riders are sighted, still far, but gaining. Isengarders redouble pace.
Land begins to slope upward. They are already passing a few trees. Pippin fears the Orcs will beat the Riders to the forest.
Rohirrim start to hem them in and are shooting stragglers.
Just short of the edge of Fangorn, the last 200 Orcs are encircled by the Rohirrim. Camp on a knoll. Night falls and clouds occasionally cover the moon.
Grishnákh of Mordor secretly carries the hobbits away from camp.
Rider kills Grishnákh. Hobbits cut their bonds, then eat lembas.
Hobbits crawl to the river, but banks are too steep to drink. They hear noise from the camp as the Riders fight off the orc reinforcements.

Sky is beginning to pale as the walk along the river to the edge of the forest. DAWN. Riders attack orcs. Hobbits watch a while, then follow the stream into Fangorn Forest as closely as the tangled woods allow.
Stop for a drink, bathe their feet and talk. Dim and stuffy. See sun shining through some way ahead.
Further than they thought. Ground rises steeply and is more stony.
Reach a ‘rock-wall’ at the foot of a barren hill. Climb rough stair to the top of the hill.
Treebeard’s Hill – Meet Treebeard.
Treebeard carries them down the hill, then turns west. They go deeper into the woods, but are never far from the stream.
Pippin asks why Celeborn warned them against Fangorn.
Treebeard chants of the woods of Beleriand.
Crest of a rise.
Valley.
Hillcrest.
Valley.
Small rise.
Ascend a ridge.
Rise even higher.
Hillcrest.
Depression.
Foothill.
A higher crest.
Dusk. Reach the foot of the mountains. Treebeard climbs the slope.
Slope climbs higher.
Continue to climb.
They reach Wellinghall, Treebeard’s home – a bay hidden behind a showering fall channeled from the spring of the Entwash. They have gone 70,000 Ent-strides.
While the hobbits sleep, Treebeard walks far summoning other Ents. Leave Wellinghall about 9 a.m. Treebeard carries them again.
Turn right, cross the young stream, and cross tumbled slopes with few trees. Birch, rowan and pines can be seen higher up.
Pippin loses count of Ent-strides at about 3000.
As he walks Treebeard chants. There are occasional responses.
They descend a last slope into deep woods with huge trees.
Treebeard sends out a summoning ‘Hoom.’ Others respond.
Treebeard sends out a summoning ‘Hoom.’ Others respond.
Treebeard sends out a summoning ‘Hoom.’ Others respond.
They pass through a dense evergreen hedge into a bowl with 3 birches: Derndingle. Entmoot begins. Hobbits wander.
Quickbeam joins them. Wander during afternoon. Stay in his house that night – close to Derndingle.
Stay with Quickbeam, but do not go far. Cold and gray. Second night at Quickbeam’s.

Dawn: bleak and windy. Voices clamour, then Forest grows silent. Ent voices explode and the march begins. Quickbeam carries the hobbits to join the others (ca.4 p.m.). Treebeard takes hobbits to carry.
Treebeard sings with the others.
Treebeard speaks again to hobbits.
Enter a long fold of land toward the south.
Stop for evening drink.
Climb up the western ridge. Woods change to scattered birch, then pines.
Sun falls behind the ridge ahead. Behind them the Huorns gather and follow.
Near the crest of the ridge, singing stops. Night falls.
Summit of hill – see Isengard below.
Creep down a long ravine
Enter the upper end of the Wizard’s Vale. Dark & cloudy.
Cross the upper waters of the Isen.
Hourns gather along the north side of Isengard.

Reach Isengard – Treebeard, hobbits and a few other ents hide near the gate of Isengard. Shortly after midnight, Saruman’s army marches forth: at least 10,000. Took over an hour. Many Huorns follow. Ents attack walls of Isengard. Quickbeam almost catches Saruman. After burning of one ent, Treebeard halts the attack.

Merry and Pippin wander all around outside the circle of Isengard. Ents gathering the waters of the Isen. At dusk Treebeard returns. Gandalf arrives. Hobbits learn of the Battle of Helm’s Deep. Treebeard warns them to avoid the gates and tunnel. At midnight the Ents break the dams they built. Isengard is flooded.
Merry and Pippin climb up a stair to the walls. During the day the Ents return the Isen to its channel. Waters start to recede.

Wormtongue arrives (ca. 9 a.m.). Treebeard sends him to Orthanc. Merry and Pippin find the store-room above the gate. Aragorn and others arrive with Théoden and Gandalf (ca. noon). After eating, they ride to Orthanc.       Confrontation with Saruman.

name: Rauros to Isengard
description: After the Breaking of the Fellowship, Aragorn, Legolas & Gimli travel to Isengard by way of Edoras.

legs.comment: Breaking of the Fellowship. Boromir slain. Pippin and Merry captured by orcs. Aragorn, Legolas and Gimli return to Parth Galen. Lay Boromir in one of the boats and send it over Rauros Falls. Seeing that Sam and Frodo have gone east, Aragorn chooses to rescue Merry and Pippin.
The ‘Three Hunters’ return to the glade where Boromir fell and pick up the orcs’ trail (ca. 4:30 p.m.).
Trail passes along many gullies and ravines which dissect the backslope of the eastern ridge of the Emyn Muil.
Descend the steep western cliff face.
Rest briefly about an hour before dawn (ca. 5 a.m.). No Camp.
They are in a stony trough between ridged hills. A trickling stream runs through the trough. Aragorn cannot see the trail in the stony land, but decides to look north.
Legolas finds 5 dead orcs. They search area.
Aragorn finds orcs’ pathway going up a ravine in the western ridge. The upper stream runs in the ravine.
Head of the stream. They continue up the ravine.
Reach crest of western ridge. Dawn. Chill wind. Legolas sees eagle. Also sees the orc company far ahead (ca. 36 miles).
Trail goes north along ridge.
Reach a narrow ravine where orcs climbed down. A noisy stream runs through it. The cliff drops ‘20 fathoms’ (120 feet) to a ‘wide and rugged shelf’ – the East Wall of Rohan.
The sheer cliff drops to the grassy plains on a path like a stony stair.
Stream disappears amid watercress. Air is warm and fragrant. They run faster.
Aragorn sees Pippin’s trail to the side and finds the Elven brooch.
Brief rest.
Brief rest.
Night falls. Camp (ca. 5:30 p.m.).
Aragorn listens to ground and hears horses galloping away from them. They leave at dawn.
Ground begins to rise toward the downs to the north (ca. 3 p.m.).
Trail bends north. Tracks become more faint on the dryer ground. Land seems empty.
Camp. Legolas fears orcs have reached Fangorn. Gathering clouds hide sliver of moon.
A red dawn. East wind.
11 a.m. Reach the first slopes of the Downs. See trampled grass from the orc camp just west of the slope. Aragorn estimates 36 hours old.
North face of southern down ridge.
Rising crest of second down ridge.
Reach most northerly hill of the Downs. Camp on hill. Cold and starry.

Dawn – east wind. Can see the Wold ahead and to the east. 15 miles away they see the Riders of Rohan. Decide to wait there. Meeting with the Riders. Éomer lends them two horses. Aragorn rides Hasufel; Legolas and Gimli: Arod. Leave ca. 11 a.m.
Find the orc trail from the East. Aragorn searches. Ride more slowly.
Overcast. Begin to find dead orcs.
Reach Fangorn and find pyre of orcs (ca. 4 p.m.). Search area. Camp by trees. Build a fire. See Saruman. Horses flee, but meet Shadowfax.
Eat at dawn. Search again.
Find mallorn leaf near knife and ropes.
See faint hobbit prints near river.
See prints of 1 hobbit at edge of trees. Enter Fangorn Forest.
Clear prints by river of both Merry and Pippin (2 days old).
Follow hobbits’ trail to foot of Treebeard’s Hill.
Climb Treebeard’s Hill. See old man below. Legolas realizes it is Gandalf!
Leave Treebeard’s Hill.
Follow the Entwash back out of the forest. Gandalf whistles for Shadowfax. Arod and Hasufel also return.
Go along bank of the Entwash.
Wade across the river at a shallow place.
Flat land, treeless and wide. Ride through meads and riverlands.
Hidden pool.
Sedge in treacherous bogs.
As sun settles toward the west, see smoke from Isengard.
Sunset.
Dusk.
Full night.
Shadowfax leads as quickly as by daylight.
Stop at last (ca. midnight). Camp only a few hours.
Continue under the moon (ca. 3 a.m.). Long clouds and chill wind.
Moon sets into clouds of the west.
Bitter chill. Dark slowly fades.
Dawn. Clear and bright. Legolas can see Meduseld.
Ford the Snowbourne. Reach a wide track. Follow it to the uplands.
Pass the burial mounds at the foot of the hill and climb to Edoras. Stopped from entering until permission is received.

Climb to Meduseld, the Golden Hall of Edoras. Gandalf heals Théoden. Rainy and windy as they exit the hall, but a shaft of sunlight shines through. Éomer is freed. Grima departs. King orders Riders to prepare to ride. Eat. Leave ca. 1 p.m.
Recross the Snowbourne.
Follow a beaten way across the foothills.
Cross a small stream.
Dusk. Camp (ca. 6 p.m.).
Rise at dawn. Depart ca. 7 a.m.
Cross a small stream.
No clouds, but hot and hazy. Dark in the east.
Cross a small stream.
Legolas can see darkness with shapes in it near the River Isen: Huorns.
Cross a small stream.
Cross a small stream.
Cross a small stream.
Dark clouds from east begin to overtake them.
Sunset. Near the mouth of the Westfold Vale. See a ride in the west.
Rider arrives. Tells them of the fall of Erkenbrand. Gandalf advises Théoden to ride for Helm’s Deep. Gandalf leaves on Shadowfax.
Host reaches the road into the Deeping Coomb. They turn south.
Night falls.
As climb upwards in the Deeping Coomb, scout reports wolf-riders.
Orc bands flee the advancing Riders.
Looking back, see torches of Saruman’s army.
Reach Helm’s Dike. It is overcast and dark.
Reach the Hornburg: the fortress of Helm’s Deep.

Past midnight. Lightning shows all the vale is filled with Saruman’s army – 10,000 strong at least. Rain begins. Battle of Helm’s Deep. Weather clears (ca. 4:30 a.m.). Uruk-hai blast an opening through the Deeping Wall. Defenders retreat to the Hornburg and the caves.
DAWN. Defenders counterattack. Gandalf arrives with Erkenbrand’s riders. Orcs flee into Huorns and are destroyed. Dunlendings surrender. King’s company rests. Departs for Isengard in afternoon (ca. 3 p.m.).
Company stops at burial mounds, then passes through Helm’s Dike.
Reach Huorns. Road continues among the ‘trees.’
Reach the end of the Huorns.
Turn west to Fords of Isen. Red after-sunset. See carrion fowl ahead.
Waxing moon rises.
Reach Fords (ca. 9:30 p.m.). The Isen is almost dry. Pass the burial mound of Erkenbrand’s riders on an islet in the riverbed.
Turn north on the highway to Isengard.
Midnight. 15 miles north of the Fords. Camp beside the river. During the night Huorns pass by. Company wakes. Later the water returns.
Dawn. Make ready to continue. Ride slowly.
Enter the south end of the Wizard’s Vale.
Pass through a wilderness of weeds and thorns. All trees cut to stumps.
Highway becomes a wide street, paved with stones.
Pass a tall pillar: the White Hand. Evidence of a flood beyond.
Reach the gates of Isengard (past noon). Meet Merry and Pippin. Aragorn, Legolas and Gimli stay at gatehouse to eat and talk.
Reach Orthanc. Confrontation with Saruman.

name: Rauros to Mt. Doom
description: After the Breaking of the Fellowship, Frodo and Sam make it all the way to Mt. Doom.

legs.comment: Breaking of the Fellowship. Noon. Frodo decides to go to Mordor alone, but Sam guesses. Reaches lake as Frodo is leaving. They go together.
Paddle past the south end of Tol Brandir.
Reach shelving shore on the south slopes of Amon Lhaw. Hide boat.
Head SE into the “strange twisted knot of hills” – the eastern Emyn Muil.
Reach south edge of the hills: “a sheer, high, impassible cliff overlooking the marshland of Nindalf ‘the Wetwang’, which lies East of the Anduin all along the delta of the Entwash.
Turn north away from the cliff.
Wind around a ravine.
Reach steep east face of inner hills. Climb down.
Camp about dusk. Hide behind boulders just back from the south-facing cliff. See glow of Gollum’s eyes.
Leave at dawn.
Climb into a gully and out. Forced to turn more to the north.
Keep as close to the cliff as can, angling southeast. Stop to eat.
Cliff curves more to the east.
Enter another ravine. Cliff still too high to descend.
Climb into another ravine. Camp at dusk.
Leave at dawn.
Cliff begins to curve much more to the north. The Wetwang curves south.
Another ravine.
Wind around rough area, forced back, away from cliff.
Continue in barren, rugged hills – not even grass. Stop to eat.
Zig-zag into ravine. The south edge of the Dead Marshes appear east of the tumbled lands below.
Get lost in ravine. Realize they are “going in circles.” Runoff from the ravine goes to the marshes.

Climb down to the bottom of another ravine. Cliff still too steep and high. Look out toward Mordor. Can smell the Dead Marshes. Go further back. Camp in a stony hollow surrounded by “great jagged pinnacles of weathered rock.” Cold.
Leave at dawn. Cliff has now turned almost due north.
Go close to the cliff, in hopes of seeing a way down.
Must swing far back, then east again. Stop to listen for signs of Gollum.
Return to cliff-top, but rough “scored and weathered rock” forces them away.
Cliff face is now lower, but they do not notice as they are not by the edge. Scramble into a deep cleft and out again.
Stop briefly. Eat.
Another cleft.
Still scrambling along back from the ridge.

Reach the deepest ravine thus far – a rock fault. Far wall is “many fathoms high.” Frodo climbs down. Finds a few gnarled trees, mainly firs, but only for about 50 yards. Stumps continue to cliff edge. As cliff is lower, Frodo decides they should descend: the rock has “slipped and cracked.” Storm arrives just as Frodo starts down. He slithers down to a rock ledge below. Sam remembers his rope and pulls Frodo up. After the storm they use the rope to descend. Dusk falls.
Head east from base of cliff, picking their way through wet boulders.
Reach a great fissure with a stream inside. It curves north: bars way.

Head back toward cliff, angling south. Too difficult to go far. No spot to hide. Stop next to a boulder. See Gollum crawling down cliff. Capture Gollum (ca. 8 p.m.). STOP, but have no rest while they watch Gollum. Late night, Frodo extracts pledge, then releases Gollum.
Start again ca. 2 a.m. Gollum leads them back north.
Reach the rift they had seen before, but farther north where sides are lower. Climb down into it (15 feet deep). Follow it south beside a “shallow stony stream.” Gollum recites ‘Fish’ riddle.
Gully turns east, broadens and grows more shallow.
Dawn. Camp in gully (day of Feb. 30) on a wide flat shelf of stone. Gully now only 6 feet deep. Frodo and Sam plan to watch, but both sleep.
Set out when dark.
Gully more shallow and less sloping.
Gully bottom less rocky.
Creek enters from north. Eat.
Floor still more muddy. Sides dwindle to mere banks.
Stream begins to wind. Sky grows cloudy.
Banks reduced to mossy mounds.

Stream gurgles over a stone shelf into the bog. Dry reeds all around. Mists rise above the Dead Marshes just ahead and on both sides. See Mountains of Mordor far ahead: wreathed in fog, lit by dawn. Rest briefly.
Gollum’s path winds through the mists, turning to find the way between “pools, and soft mires.” No birds.
As mists rise (ca. 10 a.m.), they stop for day in a reed-thicket (M. 1).
Late afternoon. Continue on.
Enter the heart of the Dead Marshes.
Round the west end of a wide stagnant mere. Air is “black and heavy to breathe.”
Wisps of lights begin to appear: “candles of corpses.” Another wide mere extends west from there.
Sam falls, sees dead faces in the water (from Battle of the Last Alliance).
They almost crawl as they founder through the treacherous mire.
Reach firmer ground (ca. 4 a.m.). Gollum trots down “a long lane between high reeds,” then stops and sniffs.
Gollum’s uneasiness grows. Hear cry of Nazgûl. Rush of wind: lights go out. Moon peaks through clouds. See Nazgûl. Gollum cowers and refuses to go on until moon is low.
Dawn. End of the marshes. Clear and cold. Mountains tower ahead across wastelands. Hide “under a black stone” during gray day (M. 2).
Leave when full dark.
Cross area of dry peat, broken by flats of cracked, dry mud. Land slopes slowly east. Ring grows heavier. Sam’s mood darkens.
Climb a long shallow slope.
Gully curves away north, then west back to the marshes.
Hide again during day (March 3).
Creep forward as dark falls. Bitter, parched air. Unknown to them, Battle of Helm’s Deep rages far to the west.
Land rises in a long slope: arid moors of the Noman-lands.
Descend a steeper hill face.
Land rises in another long slow climbing slope.
Still on the moors.

Descend a last hill face. Reach the Desolation of the Morannon: gasping pools, mounds of slag. Stop at first slag-heap, but fumes drive them away. Crawl into a “wide, almost circular pit, high-banked on the west.” An oily ooze fills bottom. Stay there (M. 4).
On waking, Sam hears Smeagol/Gollum’s debate. Sam wonders who ‘she’ is (=Shelob). At dusk, creep slowly forward.
Nazgûl passes over. Pause for a while.
Midnight. Nazgûl flies over again, but high up (on way to Isengard). Terrified, Gollum refuses to go on until ordered by Frodo.

Dawn. Can see guards on the wall above the Black Gate. Hide in a hollow “delved in the side of a low hill.” See Army of Easterlings arrive, then later, an army of Southrons. Sam recites “Oliphaunt” poem. Gollum tells of ‘secret’ way. Frodo decides to follow Gollum south. Rest during day (M. 5).
Dusk. Creep out west side of hollow.
Walk SW, west of the road. Road runs in a trenchlike valley between the mountains and the moors. It is newly repaired for many miles.
End of the slag heaps. Brief rest. Midnight: Moon rises, almost full.
Can still see the red light in one of the Towers of the Teeth.
Finally turn south enough to hide the light from the Tower.
Dawn. Reach northern edge of Ithilien. East across road are dark trees. Closer ‘a tumbled heathland’ with ‘knots of pine-trees.’ Air is fresh and fragrant. Hide in heather during day (M. 6).
Leave during twilight.
Gollum leads them onto the road: straight and level. Go more quickly.
In valley between mountains on east and steep slopes on west.
Woods appear to the west. Some growth begins along the road edges.
Road crosses stream on an arched masonry bridge.
Road becomes more overgrown.
Another stream is bridged.
Reach north end of a long straight cutting through a stony ridge.
Climb the west bank and go downhill. Follow a stream to a small clear pool. Bathe. Sam finds orc fire-ring.
Camp back toward road. Gollum brings coneys. Sam cooks stew. Eat (8:30 a.m.). Found by Southern Rangers with Faramir. Gollum hides.
Noon. Rangers battle the Haradrim. Sam sees an oliphaunt. Sleep to late afternoon. Faramir questions Frodo, then leads them west.
Cross stream below the pool.
Descend steep slope. Faramir and Frodo talk as they go.
Thread their way through woodland.
Trees grow thinner. Turn right and “come to a small river in a narrow gorge” – the same as that from the pool.
Frodo and Sam are blindfolded and led down a steep path, then up to       Henneth Annûn. Sunset gleams through the waterfall.

Moonset. Gollum fishes in waterfall pool. With Frodo’s help, Faramir captures and questions Gollum. Rest a short time more while supplies are prepared. Leave ca. 8 a.m. Rangers lead them south, blindfolded.
Faramir removes blindfolds. Advises them to follow upper edge of steep-falling lands to west.
Cross a fast stream. Brief rest. Eat.
Brief rest.
Cross a tumbling stream.
Nightfall. Sleep beneath an ancient tree. Sam restless.
Leave at first light.
Thicker trees. Brief rest. Air growing heavy. Gollum urges more speed.
Cross a small stream.
Reach area of large trees – more open: ash and oak. Gollum fearful.

Dusk. End of the forest. Can see White Mountains to the west and dark peaks of the Ephel Dúath to the east. A vale falls away before them – the Morgul. Gollum wants to continue, but they stop until midnight. Perched in an oak, the hobbits cannot sleep.
Just past midnight, head east. Land slopes up steeply. Thickets and brambles.
Cross a deep cleft.
Go around a dark pit.
Go down a bit, but then up on a longer, steeper slope.
Halt briefly. Can see tops of trees behind. Darkness begins to spread.

Climb a great ‘hogback’ – climb the steep backslope, covered with spiny thickets. Descend the even steeper cliff face. Part way down, crawl into a ‘hollow hall’ formed by a “tangled knot of thorns.” Sleep.
No dawn. Day grows even darker as time passes. Gollum wakes them (ca. 4 p.m.): “No time to lose.” Leads them down the hillside.
Turn south across a long broken slope.
Turn east and reach the Southward Road. Follow the road into a great ring of trees to the Cross-roads. The setting sun lights the fallen head of the statue of a King of Gondor.
Pass east out of the trees, following the Morgul-road. Road climbs steeply, but is straight.
At the top of a ‘flatiron’ the road cuts through the steep-faced drop and curves sharply south around a “great shoulder of rock.”
Road curves east again, next to the ravine of the Morgulduin. Way slants up steeply. Frodo glances across the vale and sees Minas Morgul.

Come to the white bridge. The road crosses it and winds up to the city gates. All is rotten, cold. Frodo totters forward as if to cross the bridge, but Sam stops him. Gollum leads them back across the road to a gap in the stone wall – a path along the slopes north of the river.
On a high shelf overlooking the city Frodo stops. The Morgul-host marches forth.
Continue up path a short way. Reach bottom of the Straight Stair. Stair is cut into the cliff with walls on each side, steps narrow, uneven, and steep as a ladder.
Above the stair, the cutting continues with a winding path – still climbing, but needs no steps: “seemed to go on for miles.”
Reach a wide shelf – cliff on left, chasm on right. No longer climbing. Ground is broken.
Reach bottom of the Winding Stair. Stair zig-zigs up the sloping cliff. Even looks down on wraith-road at one point.
Reach the top of the stairs. See red light through window in top of the Tower “a long way off.” Sleep there between two great piers of rock. All around are “jagged pinnacles...crevices and fissures.”

legs.day_full: Sleep rest of day and all night.
legs.comment: Gollum visits Shelob while the hobbits sleep.

legs.day_full: 14 miles Here, too, the time is extremely long (ca. 30 hours): “One hour, two hours...how many had they passed in this lightless hole? Hours – days, weeks, rather.”
legs.comment: “Day.” Sam wakes and sees Gollum ‘pawing at’ Frodo. ‘Sneak’ conversation. Gollum leads them “up a long ravine between piers and columns of torn and weathered rocks.”

legs.day_full: 14 miles Here, too, the time is extremely long (ca. 30 hours): “One hour, two hours...how many had they passed in this lightless hole? Hours – days, weeks, rather.”
legs.comment: Opening to Shelob’s Lair. Tunnel is so high and wide that Frodo and Sam can’t touch hands as they feel their way along each wall. Tunnel climbs slowly.

legs.day_full: 14 miles Here, too, the time is extremely long (ca. 30 hours): “One hour, two hours...how many had they passed in this lightless hole? Hours – days, weeks, rather.”
legs.comment: Sam feels an opening on the right.

legs.day_full: 14 miles Here, too, the time is extremely long (ca. 30 hours): “One hour, two hours...how many had they passed in this lightless hole? Hours – days, weeks, rather.”
legs.comment: Sam feels an opening on the right.

legs.day_full: 14 miles Here, too, the time is extremely long (ca. 30 hours): “One hour, two hours...how many had they passed in this lightless hole? Hours – days, weeks, rather.”
legs.comment: Frodo feels an opening on the left.

legs.day_full: 14 miles Here, too, the time is extremely long (ca. 30 hours): “One hour, two hours...how many had they passed in this lightless hole? Hours – days, weeks, rather.”
legs.comment: Frodo and Sam’s senses become numb, but feel things hanging down.

legs.day_full: 14 miles Here, too, the time is extremely long (ca. 30 hours): “One hour, two hours...how many had they passed in this lightless hole? Hours – days, weeks, rather.”
legs.comment: Sam leaves right wall and holds on to Frodo.

legs.day_full: 14 miles Here, too, the time is extremely long (ca. 30 hours): “One hour, two hours...how many had they passed in this lightless hole? Hours – days, weeks, rather.”
legs.comment: Frodo finds opening to main pit on left.

legs.day_full: 14 miles Here, too, the time is extremely long (ca. 30 hours): “One hour, two hours...how many had they passed in this lightless hole? Hours – days, weeks, rather.”
legs.comment: Tunnel forks. Left tunnel closed with a door. Realize Gollum is gone. Shelob appears. Use the Phial of Galadriel to drive off Shelob. Tunnel rises steeply to exit. Use Sting to cut webs.

legs.day_full: 14 miles Here, too, the time is extremely long (ca. 30 hours): “One hour, two hours...how many had they passed in this lightless hole? Hours – days, weeks, rather.”
legs.comment: Frodo runs ahead and is stung by Shelob. Sam fights off Gollum and reaches Frodo and drives off Shelob, but is too late. Thinking Frodo dead, Sam reluctantly takes the Ring and continues on.

legs.day_full: Here, too, the time is extremely long (ca. 30 hours): “One hour, two hours...how many had they passed in this lightless hole? Hours – days, weeks, rather.”
legs.comment: Sam reaches base of a flight of shallow steps to the cleft.

legs.day_full: Here, too, the time is extremely long (ca. 30 hours): “One hour, two hours...how many had they passed in this lightless hole? Hours – days, weeks, rather.”
legs.comment: From the cleft of the Pass, Sam looks back. Hearing orcs, he puts on the Ring. When orcs reach Frodo, Sam rushes back.

legs.day_full: Here, too, the time is extremely long (ca. 30 hours): “One hour, two hours...how many had they passed in this lightless hole? Hours – days, weeks, rather.”
legs.comment: Sam follows them back to closed door in the Lair. Hears orcs say Frodo is NOT dead! Climbs over the door, runs down the Under-way. Knocks himself out against the Tower door. Sleeps through night.

Noon. Sam wakes, returns through Under-way. Exits Lair. Reaches cleft by the Tower of Cirith Ungol. Puts on the Ring. Ring lets him hear fighting in the Tower. Runs over crown of the path and removes Ring. Climbs to top of the Tower and rescues Frodo.
Frodo and Sam reach gate of the Tower ca. 5 a.m. Watchers send up signal of their escape. Run. Road curves out of sight from the gate.
Road curves down sharply to meet the Morgul-road. At the bridge just beyond the road meeting, they jump. Land just a few feet below in a thorn thicket. Dawn – but dark in the valley.
Climb down to bottom of north-running valley.
Halt briefly. Sam falls asleep. Turn north in the ravine. Frodo discards chain mail. Sam wishes for light and water.
Frodo senses Black Rider. Halt again. Sky brightens. See flight of fallen Witch King – ill news for Barad-dûr. Eat a bit.
Cross over to path west of a dry stream bed. Valley rises slowly to north.
Hear water trickling from gully on left.
Road broadens and a rough wall begins: nearing an orc hold. Cross river-bed (a few pools in the bottom). Low scrubby trees. Midges.
Climb up into a ravine. Hide in brambles. Frodo sleeps. Sam sees star and also sleeps.
Continue up ravine until it disappears, then climb last 100 feet to the ridge.
Ridge stands 1500 feet above the plain. Plain is crawling with enemies. See Mount Doom 40 miles away.
Try to go north along ridge, but cannot. Retrace path back to valley floor. Stay east of water-course.
See orc hold by path on west.
Hear orc scouts. Hide behind bush. Learn news of Gollum. Light fades as they hide.
Continue in the dark along eastern edge of the valley.
Stagnant pool of water. Do not see it in the dark.
Grey light – Hide and sleep (March 17 day).
Eat. Finish Faramir’s food. When quite dark, begin again.
Brief halt.
Brief halt.
Brief halt.

At first light, hide in a hollow under an overhanging stone. Strong wind from west. Ahead the valley has climbed nearly to top of the inner ridge. Water course ends in broken steps of rock. Can see road from old castle of Durthang. Frodo sleeps. Sam finds water. Returns and sees Gollum. Wakes Frodo to watch. Sam sleeps (Day, M. 18).
Light fading when wake. See watch fires on heights. Return to spring. Fill water bottle.
Climb warily up to the road when it swings east.
A side path runs south into Gorgoroth toward main road. Sheer drop from road becomes increasingly deep.
Road bends a little north and hides view from west. Rest. Orc company sees them, assumes they are deserters. Frodo and Sam are forced to join march.
Road runs down a long slope into the plain. Frodo starts to stumble.
Out on the plain, drawing near Isenmouthe: Road-meeting.

In confusion of several companies meeting, Sam pulls Frodo with him, crawling across the road and over the curb. Crawl 20 yards to a shallow pit and sleep (late night to early morning of M. 19). Cold.
Morning. Sam sees Gorgoroth is pitted with great holes. Roads are empty. Crawl from hollow to hollow slanting toward the foothills to north.
Halt. Sam decides they should go back to road.
Climb onto the causeway.
Walk east along the road as it skirts the Ash Mountains. See no one.
Camp just off the road.
Return to road. Trudge east.
Rest.
Find cistern, but it is empty. Eat and rest.
Rest.
Camp just off road. Hear troops at night.
Return to road. More and more Frodo is bowed down by the Ring.
Rest.
Find cistern with muddied water in bottom. Drink and fill bottle. Eat.
Rest.
Camp just off road. Hear horse-messenger gallop by during night.
Return to road. Frodo ceases to speak. Stumbles as he fights Ring.
Rest.
Stop to eat. Mount Doom is due south. Leave road and turn toward it.
Rest.
The Dreadful Nightfall. Only half bottle of water left. Frodo sleeps fitfully, and Sam, very little. He sees gleam of Gollum’s eyes.
Wake in dim light of dawn. Discard everything they do not need.
Rest. No attempt at concealment. Frodo goes faster than Sam hoped.
Rest.
Extra effort squanders Frodo’s last strength. Sam cannot sleep. Argues with self. Ground trembles.
Continue on in dark light. No water. Sam’s mouth too parched to eat.
Rest.
Rest. Fumes grow worse. Some wind from the west.
Rest.
Continue to foot of Mount Doom. Sam tries to warm Frodo as he sleeps.
As attempt to start, Frodo falls and begins to crawl. Sam carries him.
Stop more than half way up base of the mountain. Rest.
Sam and Frodo both crawl up slope to Sauron’s Road. Frodo turns east and see the Eye: falls. Sam carries him again.
Gollum attacks! Sam fights Gollum. Frodo goes ahead.
Frodo enters the Door to the Sammath Naur.
Frodo claims the Ring just as Sam finds him. Gollum attacks again, bites Ring from Frodo’s finger and falls into lava. Ring Destroyed. Barad-dûr and Morannon collapse.
Escape from Mount Doom: 100 miles
Sam carries Frodo back outside. They see destruction all around.
As they go down the road, smoke and steam belch from the mountain. Reach an ash hill and climb to the top. Are cut off from going further. Both fall.

Eagles rescue Frodo and Sam and carry them to the Morannon.
Note: Why the Morannon instead of the Field of Cormallen? 
1) Gandalf is with the Eagles when Frodo and Sam are rescued, yet he is back at the Morannon after the battle in time to find Pippin.
2) Frodo and Sam must be taken to Aragorn for healing. Aragorn would be 70 miles from the Field of Cormallen and would be needed after the battle. He would not be free to leave to go to Frodo and Sam if they were elsewhere.

name: Isengard to Minas Tirith (Gandalf)
description: Gandalf and Pippin make haste to Minas Tirith.

legs.comment: Isengard. Confrontation with Saruman. Gandalf breaks Saruman’s staff. Grima Wormtongue casts down the palantír of Orthanc. Pippin retrieves it, but Gandalf quickly takes it. Leave Isengard (ca. 4 p.m.).
Pass through the gates of Isengard. Follow the stone-paved road south.
Flooded spots gradually are disappearing.
Pass the pillar of the White Hand. Ents have broken the hand apart.
Stone pavement ends. Highway continues.
Night falls. Waxing moon rises.
All around are tree stumps, weeds and thorns.
Leave the Wizard’s Vale. Highway goes SSE toward the Fords.
Reach the campsite of the night before. Turn west.

Camp (ca. 10 p.m.). In a dale next to the south-facing slope of Dol Baran, the last hill of the northern ranges. Heather and bracken fern are turning green. While Gandalf sleeps, Pippin takes the palantír and is seen by Sauron. Gandalf plans to ride out at once with Pippin. When a Nazgûl rides over, he warns Théoden to not wait for the dawn to leave.
Gandalf and Pippin return to the highway and turn south (ca. 11 p.m.).
Shadowfax reaches the west bank by the Fords of Isen.
Midnight. Shadowfax crosses the Fords of Isen.
Gandalf points out the peaks of the Thrihyrne to the south. He tells Pippin the history of the palantíri – the Seeing Stones of Gondor.
Reach the road to the Deeping Coomb and Helm’s Deep. Gandalf tells Pippin to ask Gimli about the Glittering Caves of Aglarond. Gandalf urges Shadowfax to even greater speed.
Cross a small stream. Brief stop. Eat.
Cross a small stream.
Cross a small stream.
